title: Bankston Cameos in Citizenfour, Bacon, Jr. Cameos in Season 3 of House of Cards, and More
html:
Roll out the Red Carpet! Two New Americans have made their screen debuts!

  • Kevin Bankston has a cameo in one of the opening scenes of Citizenfour, which opened October 2014 and recently won the Oscar for best documentary. Kevin is featured (as himself) from his 2011 oral argument in front of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the surveillance lawsuit Jewel v. NSA.
  • Perry Bacon Jr. has a cameo in the first episode of Season 3 of House of Cards, which just came out on February 27. Perry appears on-screen (as himself) discussing President Underwood’s approval ratings on the news.
  • Also available for viewing: Hao Wu’s documentary, “The Road to Fame” is on Comcast/Xfinity On Demand the month of March.

POLICY

  • On Monday, OTI published and filed a report with the FCC recommending that the Commission delay approving the appointment of Telcordia as the new Local Number Portability Administrator (LNPA), replacing Neustar, until the agency considers the potential impacts on market competition, public safety and the IP technology transition.
  • The Net Neutrality order was released on Thursday and Michael Calabrese shares that it is as good for the public interest as hoped and expected. Michael was quoted in a wide range of leading industry press about the order.

BOOKS

  • Kevin Carey launched his new book, The End of College. Kevin was interviewed about the book by NPR's Fresh Air, which was syndicated by over fifty public and online radio stations. He was also interviewed by WAMC Northeast Public Radio and by WNYC's Brian Lehrer. The book was written about in The New York Times, The Atlantic, and The New Republic. The New York Times piece was syndicated in several publications including The Seattle Times. Kevin also had an op-ed published in CNN, and he was quoted in The New York Times about the monopoly colleges have over credentialism.
  • Peter W. Singer’s cybersecurity book, Cybersecurity and Cyberwar: What Everyone Needs to Know, just made the professional reading list for Air Force officers.
  • Levi Tilleman’s book, The Great Race: The Global Quest for the Car of the Future, and Steve LeVine’s book, The Powerhouse: Inside the Invention of a Battery to Save the World were both reviewed by The Washington Post (earlier this month, Levi and Steve enjoyed another double-book review, as both books were reviewed by The Economist. )

EVENTS

  • OpenITP successfully hosted a six-day Circumvention Tech Festival in Valencia, Spain, which included hundreds of participants from around the world and a variety of related events throughout the week.
  • Sarah Morris spoke on the closing panel at the Freedom 2 Connect conference in New York City, where she and other advocates discussed "The Amazing Network Neutrality Coalition" and the organizing efforts that helped win the net neutrality fight.
  • Yascha Mounk organized a packed panel at America NYC recently with Elif Batuman, Jamelle Bouie, Sam Goldman and Sarah Leonard on the topic of The Age of Exhaustion: Can Old Ideas Make Sense of a New World?
  • On March 9, Peter Singer led a strategy session at US Marine Corps University for its leaders on cybersecurity, and on March 11, Peter spoke to a new group of US Army one-star generals about the Future of War.

BEST OF THE BLOGS

  • EdCentral: Education Policy recommends reading Jason Delisle’s post about the good news for Pell Grants that the CBO’s annual cost projection brings, and Conor Williams’ post about how “Pre-K Works Especially Well for Children of Immigrants.”
  • South Asia Channel: ISP recommend an excellent piece on the on the rise of the AAP in India written by Neeli Shah.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • New America's recently-launched Medium publication has generated a terrific response, including being selected as one of the sites included in their limited beta launch of custom domains. You can read about the launch here, and can now find our publication at context.newamerica.org. We look forward to including more of your stories as we grow this publication! Contact Jane Carr (carr@newamerica.org) for more information!
  • Jason Delisle and Alexander Holt's new paper, "Why Student Loans Are Different" was covered by The Chronicle of Higher Education and Inside Higher Ed.
  • Ari Ratner and Julian Zelizer shared their assessments of the impact of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech to Congress on CNN.com. Related: Suzanne DiMaggio was quoted in the Wall Street Journal about the Obama administration’s negotiations with Iran.
  • Rachel Fishman was on NPR's Morning Edition and All Things Considered discussing how to simplify the FAFSA.
  • Dan Kurtz-Phelan reviewed The Strategist for the New York Times.
  • Peter Bergen wrote two articles for CNN.com this week: one about the decline and fall of bin Laden, and one about bin Laden’s Afghan hideout.
  • Elizabeth Weingarten and Leila Hilal published an article in Foreign Policy, about Afghanistan launching the National Action Plan, to promote the role of women in peacemaking.
  • Yascha Mounk wrote a piece on the op-ed page of the Wall Street Journal, arguing that Germany, rather than using its power to impose a political vision on the rest of Europe, has been content to free-rise on its allies.
  • Peter W. Singer shares that his blog at Popular Science, Eastern Arsenal, just celebrated it’s first anniversary, with “90 articles in total, 1.3 million readers, and 1 military monkey.”

title: Drutman Publishes Book on Lobbying, New America Holds Second Event on Race in America, and More
html:
POLICY

  • On March 18, OTI Senior Policy Counsel Laura Moy testified before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing, and Trade on the consumer privacy issues related to the new data breach bill. Here's her written testimony.
  • Peter W. Singer spoke to Marines at the US Marine Base Quantico about cybersecurity.

BOOKS

  • Lee Drutman’s book, The Business of America is Lobbying, was published this week. He’ll be discussing more about the book with NPR’s Peter Overby at an event on April 16h at New America. Register here!

EVENTS

  • New America hosted the second event in the "From Moment to Movement" Series: Conversations on Race in America in collaboration with Howard University, exploring the topic “Broken Windows or Broken Badges? Can Reform Improve Policing?” Kirsten Holtz helped organize the event, which was moderated by Laurenellen McCann. Participants included Sgt. Delroy A. Burton (Chairman, DC Police Union), Dr. Greg Carr (Associate Professor & Chair, The Department of Afro-American Studies, Howard University), Tanya Clay House (Director of Public Policy, Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights Under Law), and Alex Altman (TIME).
  • Suzanne DiMaggio spoke at J Street's national conference on a panel focused on the nuclear negotiations with Iran with Amb. Tom Pickering and Brig. General Shlomo Brom.

BEST OF THE BLOGS

  • South Asia Channel: Ali Karimi wrote an excellent article about how Afghanistan must catch-up in urbanization, so that it does not continue to fall behind, and Michael Kugelman wrote a piece about Afghan President Ashraf Ghani’s upcoming trip to Washington DC.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Peter W. Singer launched the first episode of “The Cybersecurity Podcast,” a new venture between New America and “Passcode,” the Christian Science Monitor ‘s cybersecurity section. Peter will host the podcast along with Sara Sorcher, editor of “Passcode.” Read more about it in FP’s The Best Defense, and tune in to the new podcast here! Peter was also spoke on two panels at SXSW, and was quoted in a Washington Post article about Pakistan deploying drones against terrorists.
  • Opportunity@Work and co-founder Byron Auguste were featured in a Fortune Mag piece about the future of job search, which will focus on closing the information gap between companies and people looking for work.  
  • The recent ISP hosted event with General Michael Hayden received a write-up in The Guardian.
  • Peter Bergen and David Sterman published an article on CNN.com about the attack in Tunisia, and ISP’s work on right wing extremism was cited in an article by The Atlantic.
  • Douglas Ollivant was interviewed on the PBS Newshour about the battle for Tikrit.
  • Rebecca MacKinnon was interviewed on Marketplace this week, about the cost of keeping social media sites in check.
  • NYT columnist Joe Nocera devoted his March 10th column to Kevin Carey’s new book, End of College. Kevin’s new book was also mentioned in the Washington Post, Portland Press Herald, Times Union, and the Christian Science Monitor.
  • EdCentral's latest policy paper "Why Student Loans Are Different" by Jason Delisle and Alexander Holt was mentioned in Pacific Standard.
  • Conor Williams wrote an op-ed for Talking Points Memo.
  • Shane Harris was on the Diane Rehm Show’s Friday News Roundup.

title: Bankston Organizes Bipartisan Coalition Letter About USA PATRIOT Act, Gopal to Win Award for Book on Afghanistan, and More
html:
POLICY

  • FCC in a conference call late Friday confirmed that the 3.5 GHz CBRS Order (and Further Notice) is on circulation for approval at April meeting. Dynamic sharing of this mostly-unused Navy radar band – 150 megahertz – was originally a WiFu/OTI idea to permit (Michael Calabrese’s 2011 TPRC paper: “Use it or Share it”). We worked it through PCAST – and Wheeler embraced it (in part because he was an advisor to PCAST). This is a HUGE precedent for a paradigm shift from auctioning to dynamic sharing.
  • On March 18, Peter Bergen and the International Security Program team met with officials from Australia's Office of National Assessments to share their initial findings regarding foreign fighters who have left for Syria.
  • The FBI just released its report "The FBI Protecting the Homeland in the 21st Century," the Congressionally directed 9/11 Review Commission and it cites Peter Bergen and David Sterman's CNN article on Anwar Awlaki's influence.
  • OTI's Kevin Bankston successfully organized a rare major coalition effort between the Internet industry and civil society organizations on Wednesday March 25, sending a bipartisan coalition letter with dozens of company and NGO signers demanding that Congress pass significant surveillance reform legislation as part of its anticipated reauthorization of expiring USA PATRIOT Act surveillance provisions this spring. The letter was covered in the Washington Post, by Politico Pro and Politico's Morning Tech, and the Hill, amongst others.
  • In a win for OTI and Wireless Future - on Friday March 27, FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler circulated an order proposing rules for the shared use of the 3.5 GHz band, is on circulation for approval at an April 17 meeting. Michael Calabrese shares that “Dynamic sharing of this mostly-unused Navy radar band – 150 megahertz – was originally a WiFu/OTI idea to permit” (from Michael’s2011 TPRC paper: “Use it or Share it’) Michael adds this this is a significant precedent for “a paradigm shift from auctioning to dynamic sharing.
  • Danielle Kehl traveled Brussels to present OTI's Cost of Connectivity research to Members of the European Parliament, their staff, and journalists.
  • Peter W. Singer gave a speech on cybersecurity at a multiagency retreat at the Foreign Service Institute.
  • On March 27, Sharon Burke spoke at the official premiere of The Burden (a documentary on military energy) at the US Navy Memorial as part of the DC Environmental Film Festival. Sharon is also in the film!

BOOKS

  • Anand Gopal will receive the 2015 Ridenhour Book Prize for No Good Men Among the Living: America, the Taliban, and the War Through Afghan Eyes. The Ridenhour Book Prize is awarded annually to honor an outstanding work of social significance from the prior publishing year and recognizes investigative and reportorial distinction.
  • Kevin Carey's new book The End of College was reviewed in the New York Times Sunday Book Review and the book was named on the Washington Post's best seller list. He was interviewed for Inside Higher Ed about the book. The book was also written about in the National Review, Today, Fast Company, and NPR Wisconsin Public Radio. Kevin also wrote an op-ed for the Washington Post.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Anne-Marie Slaughter published her latest Project Syndicate column, “A Raisin in the Israeli Sun.”
  • Byron Auguste and Opportunity@Work were featured in an article in Fortune, about producing a more efficient and effective marketplace for workers and employers.
  • Georgia Levenson Keohane’s article on NYC closing the gender gap in entrepreneurship, “The New Recipe for Women Entrepreneurs to Find Success,” was picked up by Time and the World Economic Forum, and was re-tweeted by Sally Krawcheck and Chelsea Clinton.
  • Hua Hsu published an article on music and globalization in this week's issue of the New Yorker:
  • Leah Douglas published an article this week in Fortune, that discusses a bill in Nebraska that would overturn that state's ban on meat packers owning hogs, thereby opening the door to contract farming and threatening independent hog farmers' ability to compete in an open market.
  • Lee Drutman published an opinion piece in the Washington Post, “Despite Citizens United, elections aren’t a good investment for corporations.”
  • Stephen Burd published an article in the Hechinger Report about low-income students pursuing college.
  • Ben Miller had an article published in The Chronicle of Higher Education on student loan default rates and was quoted in AZCentral.

title: ISP Report Featured on Last Week Tonight, Weekly Wack Named Best Think Tank April Fools' Issue, and More
html:
ON THE BIG SCREEN

  • The International Security Program’s January 2014 report, Do NSA’s Bulk Surveillance Programs Stop Terrorists? (authored by Peter Bergen, David Sterman, Emily Schneider and Bailey Cahall) was recently featured on an episode of Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, about the efficacy of such programs in identifying and preventing terrorist threats.
  • Former New America Carnegie Fellow Saba Imtiaz's novel "Karachi You're Killing Me!" will soon become a Bollywood movie.

POLICY

  • Anne-Marie Slaughter and Suzanne DiMaggio joined a bipartisan group of over 50 retired military officials, U.S. foreign policy leaders, Ambassadors, and leading national security experts in applauding the announcement of the Iran framework agreement.
  • OTI Policy Counsel Robyn Greene participated in a Senate briefing on the Senate Intelligence Committee’s Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act (CISA) on Thursday. On Friday, she participated in a briefing hosted by the Advisory Committee to the Congressional Internet Caucus titled, “Cyber Security: Will the Sharing of Threat Information Secure the Homeland or Erode Privacy?”
  • After finishing its pilot study, the Ranking Digital Rights team convened stakeholder meetings in New York City, Washington, DC, Berlin, Budapest, and London to collect feedback. The team will now revise the methodology and research process in preparation for a public ranking to be released later this year.
  • Rebecca MacKinnon presented the project at RightsCon in Manila, where she also spoke on panels about the Global Network Initiative, the need for remedy when people experience human rights violations online, the need for frameworks to address cross-border requests to remove online content, and the meaning of democracy in a networked era.
  • Peter W. Singer was the closing speaker at the annual US Army Strategy conference, exploring key principles for future US strategy.
  • New America and OTI alum, Josh Breitbart was officially named a special advisor for broadband in the New York City Mayor's Office, where he'll be continuing to do a lot of the good work that he and other members of the field team started at OTI.

PUBLICATIONS

  • ISP Fellow Phil Mudd has a new book come out April 6th, titled, The HEAD Game: High-Efficiency Analytic Decision Making and the Art of Solving Complex Problems Quickly.
  • Chris Leonard’s book, THE MEAT RACKET: The Secret Takeover of America’s Food Business was recently featured in the New York Times’ Paperback Row, described as “a brilliantly detailed portrait of the behemoth Tyson Foods and its extensive control of the country’s meat industry.”
  • Kevin Carey's book The End of College was mentioned in the New York Times Sunday Book Review, U.S. News, Forbes, Library of Economics and Liberty, Inside Higher Ed, the Conversation, the Chronicle of Higher Education (twice), The Atlantic, The Economist, The Hill News, and Washington Monthly.

EVENTS

  • The Museum of the City of New York has an exhibit and set of programming related to activism, and is jointly exploring/discussing with New America NYC, new kinds of activism, what it looks like in NYC (and beyond) today. The first event will be one on 'urban green innovators’ (which Georgia Levenson Keohane will be participating in) and if that goes well, there might be further events - one on the living wage (July) and one on measuring poverty (October).
  • On April 2, Hollie Russon-Gilman served on a Google Hangout for the World Bank to 16,000 followers about Citizen Engagement.
  • Sharon Burke continues to speak widely on energy security related issues. On April 2, Sharon spoke at "U.S. Refining and Crude Oil Exports" at CSIS; on April 8, Levi Tillemann joined Sharon for a lecture she gave to the Clean Energy Leadership Institute; and on April 10, she spoke at the Environmental Law and Policy Annual Review Conference on on the "Military-Environmental Complex."

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Think Tank Watch, a blog which according to itself is "The World's Top Source for Think Tank News & Information" says that New America had the best think tank April Fools' issue, with The Weekly Wack spoof of the The Weekly Wonk.
  • New America's Medium publication channel, context.newamerica.org, was featured as "Driving New Discourse in Publications" in a piece, "Four Ways Medium Can Work for Social Impact Orgs." Medium also gave a shout-out to Lindsey Tepe's piece on micro-credentials in Bright, a new publication they launched last month with the Gates Foundation.
  • Suzanne DiMaggio did a series of interviews related to the Iran nuclear negotiations, with two appearances on The Alex Witt Show on MSNBC, discussing the prospects for an agreement and on the framework and next steps; speaking with The New York Times (on background) for an editorial that ran on 2 April, “A Promising Nuclear Deal with Iran,” and with POLITICO, on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s reactions to the deal, and what that could mean for her presidential campaign. Suzanne also participated in a press briefing organized by The National Security Network on the framework agreement, which focused on reactions in Iran to the agreement and implications for U.S.-Iran relations.
  • Sharon Burke was quoted in Washington Life’s coverage of “The Burden” - the documentary about the military energy that premiered last week at the DC Environmental Film Festival.
  • Liza Mundy has a book review in Washingtonian this month. It's about Nora Pouillon, the local restauranteur and founder of Nora, but since part of the memoir is about her early experiences as a woman entrepreneur and business owner, in the male-dominated restaurant/chef culture.
  • Courtney Schuster made her debut publication on CNN.com, co-authoring an article about Al-Shabaab with Peter Bergen.
  • Julian Zelizer published an article on CNN.com about Hillary Clinton’s candidacy, and was interviewed on MSNBC and CNBC about 2016 GOP candidates.
  • Michael Waltz did a number of interviews relating to the Berghdal charges, including with CNN and Fox.
  • Faine Greenwood published an article on TIME.com about digital humanitarianism.
  • The Knight Foundation cross-posted a write-up of that Ranking Digital Rights accomplished at RightsCon.
  • Slate published a post Priya Kumar wrote about Facebook's new Scrapbook feature.
  • Tyler Bugg served as editor for the Roosevelt Institute Campus Network's 10 Ideas in Equal Justice journal, a journal of the 10 best student-devised policy recommendations for social issues in 2015.
  • David Gray wrote an op-ed in RealClearPolicy about community college reform.

title: Slaughter and Beinart Join Zakaria on CNN, FCC Votes to Employ OTI Proposal, and More
html:
SEEN ON SCREEN

  • Three out of four ain't bad! Anne-Marie Slaughter and Peter Beinart joined New America Trustee Fareed Zakaria’s CNN program on April 12, for a “GPS all star panel on Hillary Clinton, Iran and Cuba."

POLICY

  • OTI and the Wireless Future Project had one of their “big ideas” adopted on Friday April 17, when the FCC voted 5-0 to create a new Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) that opens a large band of Navy radar spectrum for shared and unlicensed use. Wireless Future Project originally proposed opening this band for small cell, unlicensed spectrum sharing in 2011. Michael Calabrese co-authored the 2012 PCAST report recommending the 3.5 GHz band for initial implementation of dynamic spectrum sharing of underutilized Federal band.

EVENTS

  • Suzanne DiMaggio participated as a guest speaker in a roundtable on the impact of sanctions on human rights and democratic reform in Iran that was organized by The Carter Center on April 16.
  • Peter W. Singer briefed a group of Fortune 100 CEOs and CIOs on cyber issues.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Lee Drutman published an article in The Washington Post about what the public gets wrong about lobbying and corruption. Lee also published a piece in The Atlantic about how corporate lobbyists conquered American democracy, and received a shoutout for his book from Ezra Klein at VOX. He was tweeted by Ralph Nader!
  • Konstantin Kakaes published an article in The Washington Post, about how flying a drone can be a form of civil disobedience.
  • Georgia Levenson Keohane published an article in TIME about why GDP is a bad measure of our economy.
  • Peter W. Singer coordinated a Future of War team survey with Defense One.
  • Jenny Lu Mallamo’s takeaway on the role of the media in bridging the civil-military divided was published in TIME and in Pacific Standard Magazine.
  • Lindsey Tepe's article on using micro-credentials to improve teacher professional development, "The Next Experiment in Education," was published in Time.
  • The Southern Poverty Law Center's Mark Potok cited the International Security Program’s work on right wing extremists in a piece on the Oklahoma City Bombing anniversary in Politico Magazine.
  • Ben Miller was quoted in the LA Times about Corinthian Colleges which was syndicated in around fifteen local newspapers. He was also quoted about a similar subject in an Associated Press article that was posted in U.S. News and syndicated in over 100 local and online publications. He was then quoted in Buzzfeed and the Chronicle of Higher Education about Corinthian Colleges.
  • Stephen Burd spoke on the NPR show "On Point" about economic inequality in college admissions.
  • Julian Zelizer analyzed the biggest campaign mistakes so far in the 2016 campaign that is underway in a piece for CNN.com. He also talked about LBJ and the Great Society on WNYC’s The Brian Lehrer Show, and was also quoted in The Guardian about Hillary Clinton’s campaign and candidacy.

title: #ExploreNewAmerica Trends Nationwide, OTI Spearheads Blocking of Comcast-Time Warner Merger, and More
html:
Of course, the New America Annual Conference is the big win last week! We’ll have a full report on media hits next week. Congrats to everyone for a great event, but pretty cool to know that the official event hashtag, #explorenewamerica, was trending nationally!

MAKING HEADLINES!

Anand Gopal, 2014 Schwartz Fellow, was one of the two finalists in the Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction, for No Good Men Among the Living. The official announcement described Anand’s book as: ‘a remarkable work of nonfiction storytelling that exposes the cascade of blunders that doomed America’s misbegotten intervention in Afghanistan. This was Anand’s first book, so a tremendous achievement!

Sheri Fink, a New America Fellows Program alum and current Senior Future Tense Fellow, was part of the New York Times team that was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for international reporting for their coverage of the ebola crisis. Read some of Sheri’s excellent reporting here.

Andrea Elliott received the University Medal for Excellence from Columbia University, which awarded annually to an outstanding Columbia graduate under the age of 45. Andrea is an alumna and Valedictorian of the Journalism school. Andrea’s five-part series in 2013, Invisible Child, won the George Polk Award for Local Reporting, the Scripps Howard Award for Human Interest Reporting and the David Aronson Award for Social Justice Reporting, among other honors. Her three-part series, An Imam in America, won the 2007 Pulitzer Prize for Feature Writing.

POLICY IMPACT

  • In a big win for OTI — and consumers — the nation's largest cable companies, Comcast and Time Warner Cable, abandoned their planned merger last week after the FCC and DOJ indicated they would block the deal. Joshua Stager, who led OTI's efforts against the deal at the FCC, DOJ, and Congress, said the merger "would have given Comcast the power to stifle small businesses, raise consumer prices, and undermine the Internet economy."
  • Congratulations to OTI's Field Team, whose Resilient Mesh Wireless project will be announced as a winner of RISE:NYC, a New York City Economic Development Corporation competition to identify and deploy creative new technologies to promote recovery from Superstorm Sandy and mitigate the impacts of future storms, floods and power outages. The Resilient Mesh Wireless project is a series of local networks serving small businesses combined with Digital Stewards trainings in Sandy-affected areas, designed to make New York City more resilient.The project builds on OTI’s experience deploying resilient local networks in the field, particularly supporting the Red Hook WiFi network (another winner of RISE:NYC).
  • Peter W. Singer had an in-person meeting with Secretary of the Navy Ray Mabus, to discuss an early version of Peter’s upcoming book, Ghost Fleet (out June 2015). Peter also spoke at Navy conference on April 22, on strategy for 2020s. Also on the panel was Mark Hagerott, a new non resident expert with New America, so half the panel and all the think tankers were from New America!
  • The new National Defense Authorization bill from the House reflects a number of ideas from Rosa Brooks and Peter W. Singer, notably the mandate ordering more advanced tech war-games. Rosa and Peter had been 2 of the 4 experts invited to testify before the House Armed Services Subcommittee on Emerging Threats session on February 5, looking at the future of U.S. National Security.
  • Last week, Representative Joe Crowley (D-NY), the Vice Chair of the Democratic Caucus released, "Building Better Savings, Building Brighter Futures" a report that calls for reforms to improve opportunities for Americans to save, build financial security, and ensure a secure retirement. The report features several reforms based on proposals made by the Asset Building Program. The report calls for:
    • A universal system of children's savings accounts and proposes USAccounts, a variation of the Asset Building Program's ASPIRE proposal.
    • A new tax credit to support savings for low- and moderate-income families for a variety of purposes, including retirement, education and emergency savings, as proposed by the Asset Building Program's Financial Security Credit.
    • Removing savings disincentives known as asset limits in public assistance programs, as proposed by the Asset Building Program.
  • Ian Wallace and Tim Maurer both spoke at the Global Conference on Cyberspace in the Hague last week, joined also by Rob Morgus. GCCS is significant in the cybserspace community, so it was great to have New America’s Cybersecurity Initiative well represented. Learn more Ian, Tim and Rob’s involvement here.

BOOKS

  • Congratulations to Liza Mundy, who received a contract to write a book about the women who were recruited by the Army and Navy to work as codebreakers during WWII. Here’s the official announcement from Publisher’s Marketplace:
  • New York Times bestselling journalist Liza Mundy’s CODE GIRLS, pitched as The Girls of Atomic City meets “The Imitation Game,” about the sisterhood of American women at the U.S. Army’s Arlington Hall, some of them still living today, who were recruited as code breakers during World War Two, and whose efforts helped lead to Allied victory, moving to Paul Whitlatch at Hachette Books, in a major deal, in a pre-empt, by Todd Shuster of Zachary Shuster Harmsworth Literary Agency (NA).

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Lee Drutman had two New York Times wins: on April 24, he published a column in the Opinion Pages, A Better Way to Rein in Lobbying, and on April 22, he was cited by Tom Edsall.
  • Peter Bergen’s article asking whether U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein could have been saved, was the lead article on CNN.com on Friday April 24.
  • Yascha Mounk wrote an article for Die Zeit about the disadvantages of Germany's policy of austerity and the failure of German media even to represent the consensus of economists in the UK and the US.
  • Lisa Guernsey published an article in the New York Times about babies' interaction with iPads.

title: New America NYC Hosts Event with Iran's Foreign Minister, Bankston Testifies at House Oversight Committee Hearing, and More
html:
CONTINUING TO TREND!

The official event hashtag for the April 29th New America NYC event, #ZarifNYC, was trending nationally!

POLICY IMPACT

  • Suzanne DiMaggio and New America NYC hosted an event with Iran's Foreign Minister Javad Zarif that was moderated by The Washington Post's David Ignatius in NYC on 29 April. The event generated extensive national and international press/media coverage (including in The New Yorker, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, The Guardian, AP, Reuters) and trended nationally on Twitter. Later that afternoon, Suzanne helped to convene a private discussion that brought together Zarif and Iran's nuclear negotiating team with former U.S. senior officials and diplomats. She also organized a small, private dinner with Zarif on 31 April as part of the U.S.-Iran Track II Dialogue she directs.
  • Last Wednesday, OTI's Kevin Bankston testified to the House Oversight Committee at a hearing on potential US policy responses to encryption technology, where his testimony focused on 10 reasons why a government mandate to require surveillance backdoors into encrypted products and services would undermine America's cybersecurity and economic security while also threatening civil liberties. All of the Representatives in attendance were aligned with OTI's positions and aggressively questioned law enforcement using arguments taken from Kevin's written testimony, as reflected in coverage by the Washington Post and the Christian Science Monitor among others. Several commentators noted how they had never before seen such unanimous opposition to the government on an issue of law enforcement and national security post-9/11.

    (Front Row: Kevin Bankston testifying before Congress. Second Row: Danielle Kehl and Andi Wilson)
  • The USA FREEDOM Act, the surveillance reform bill regarding which OTI has been leading a broad coalition of civil society organizations and Internet companies in support, was re-introduced last week and approved by the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday morning by an overwhelming vote. It will proceed to the House floor when Representatives return from recess next week. It is expected to pass the House but prospects in the Senate are much less clear, as the June 1st deadline for renewal of the USA PATRIOT Act quickly approaches.
  • Congratulations to Mark Hagerott, a member of the Future of War team, who has been named the next chancellor of the North Dakota University system!

BOOKS/PUBLICATIONS

  • OTI released a new policy paper, "Controlling Internet Infrastructure: The IANA Transition and Why It Matters for the Future of the Internet," the first in a series of papers by OTI Senior Fellow and esteemed cyberlaw professor David Post and Senior Policy Analyst Danielle Kehl on the U.S. government's decision to end its formal oversight over Internet governance in 2015.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Both keynote speakers from New America’s Annual Conference contributed pieces to CNN.com, based on their remarks. Read Senator Booker’s here: What’s Better for America’s Status?, and read Governor Kasich’s here: How to turn America around. Governor Kasich’s keynote also received coverage from CNN, Bloomberg, USA Today, and US News and World Report.
  • New America's Medium publication, Context, also published a roster of terrific content generated by last week's Annual Conference--including expanded versions of the essays in the program by Byron Auguste & Tyra Mariani, Hollie Russon Gilman, Virginia Eubanks, and Elmira Bayrasli. Virginia's essay on the risks of policy by algorithm was also published on Slate.
  • Laurenellen McCann and Hollie Russon-Gilman will be contributing editors for Civicist, a new hub for news and analysis of the civic tech world launched by Civil Hall. Both Hollie and Laurenellen wrote pieces to accompany the launch on May 1st.
  • Two former New America fellows appeared in the New York Times recently with writing on the murder of Pakistani rights advocate Sabeen Mahmud in Karachi. Former Carnegie Fellow Raza Rumi, who himself was targeted by gunmen for his journalism wrote an op-ed titled "Sabeen Mahmud, Martyr for Free Speech" and Saba Imtiaz, another former Carnegie Fellow, wrote the Times' report on the murder.
  • One of ISP’s South Asia channel researchers, Neeli Shah, wrote a great piece on net neutrality in India for Foreign Policy--.
  • With the ongoing disaster response in Nepal, Faine Greenwood wrote an article in Slate about the practical role drones can play in responding to the disaster, and help fill in the gaps - especially with the Nepal does not have enough manned helicopters available.
  • Michael Lind published an article in POLITICO Magazine, Why Both Sides Are Wrong About Trade.
  • Lee Drutman wrote an article, The solution to lobbying is more lobbying, that was published in the Washington Post’s Monkey Cage blog.

title: Sterman Discusses Homegrown Terrorism on CNN, Bergen Testifies Before Senate Committee, and More
html:
Congratulations to David Sterman of ISP, who made his CNN debut on May 7th, discussing homegrown terrorism!

(David Sterman, speaking about ISIS’ American recruits on CNN)

Meredith Hanley shares that NewDeal - a national network of pro-growth progressive state and local leaders - mentioned Andy Berke (one of their members) and New America’s Annual Conference is their newsletter.

POLICY IMPACT

  • On May 7, Peter Bergen testified before a hearing the Senate Committee on Homeland and Governmental Affairs held on Jihad 2.0: Social Media in the Next Evolution of Terrorist Recruitment. Media outlets that covered the hearing, included: ABC News, The Intercept, and Reuters.

    (Peter Bergen, testifying before the before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee)
  • Laura Moy of OTI was appointed to the FCC's Consumer Advisory Committee. The mission of the Committee, which has 37 members, is to make recommendations to the Commission regarding consumer issues within the jurisdiction of the Commission and to facilitate the participation of consumers in proceedings before the Commission.
  • Peter W. Singer led a multi-agency session for the intelligence community on new tech and strategy of the future.
  • Heather Hurlburt briefed the Peace and Security Funders' Group --the leading funder affinity group on intl security grantmaking, with MacArthur, Carnegie, Skoll, Rockefeller Brothers, Ploughshares etc., on what the New Models of Policy Change project suggests for a 2015-16 legislative advocacy strategy.
  • On May 8, Douglas Ollivant spoke to a group of 60 officers from the National Defense University’s Joint and Combined Warfighting School.
  • On May 8, Ian Wallace spoke to the State Dept’s International Visitors Leadership Program ‘US Foreign Policy’ group on ‘Cybersecurity’ and ‘Think Tank in the US’.

EVENTS

  • On Friday April 24, Rebecca MacKinnon delivered the closing keynote titled “Fostering a Positive Digital Environment for Citizen Engagement and Participation” at a conference organized by UCLA’s World Policy Forum called “Monitoring and Accountability: Supporting Governments to Meet Their Commitments.” Rebecca was also at the Freedom Online Coalition conference in Ulan Bator, Mongolia where she spoke on a plenary panel called “Future Internet Trends.” Rebecca was also one of the speakers in a workshop presenting the research carried out by the coalition’s Working Group on Privacy and Transparency, of which she is a member along with Kevin Bankston. OTI’s Liz Woolery carried out core components of the research presented at the conference.
  • Georgia Levenson Keohane co-hosted with the Museum of the City of New York a first in a series about new forms of activism, called the New New York Activists. This event was entitled The New New York Activists: Urban Green Innovators. The Huffington Post also wrote about the event.
  • Hollie Russon-Gilman judged a Hack4Congress not just for technologists hackathon at Google aimed to improve citizens relationship with congress, and was also part of a Twitter hang out on New Urban Practice with Living Cities.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Suzanne DiMaggio met with members of The New York Times Editorial Board to discuss U.S.-Iran relations following a nuclear deal.
  • Peter Bergen wrote an article for CNN on the shooting at the cartoon contest, and another article for CNN (co-authored with David Sterman), about ISIS’ American recruits.
  • Rabia Chaudry published an article in Slate on what Ayaan Hirsi Ali does not understand about Muslims in America.
  • Hua Hsu wrote several pieces for the New Yorker recently, including one on Umberto Eco's guide to writing a thesis and what it says about the humanities (which was one of the most read/shared pieces at the newyorker.com), and a piece on Paul Beatty, Kendrick Lamar and art in the age of Obama.
  • Lee Drutman published an article on TIME.com, about what Comcast’s failed merger taught us about corporate lobbying.
  • Kevin Carey published an article in Pacific Standard about AltSchool and another about Kevin Suppes. He was interviewed about his book the End of College for U.S. News.
  • Byron Auguste, Tyra Mariani, and Opportunity@Work received a shout out in a Time.com article, How Tech Entrepreneurs Are Overcoming Washington’s Dysfunction.
  • Julian Zelizer wrote a CNN.com piece, Where Liberalism Can Win in America, that also referenced New America’s recent Annual Conference.
  • Conor Williams published an op-ed in Talking Points Memo about the Republican Party.
  • Ben Miller participated in the New York Times Room for Debate blog about loan forgiveness.
  • Steve Burd published an interview in the Hechinger Report with Joshua Steckel about leveling the playing field for low-income students.

title: Two OTI Testimonies Given in the House, Leonard Featured on Last Week Tonight, and More
html:
POLICY IMPACT

  • On May 13, Danielle Kehl testified before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Communications and Technology in a hearing on "Stakeholder Perspectives on the IANA Transition," which was the subject of a recent OTI paper written by Danielle and OTI Senior Fellow David Post. You can read her written testimony here.

    (Danielle Kehl testifying before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Communications and Technology)
  • On Thursday May 14, Laura Moy testified before the House Financial Services Committee at a hearing titled “Protecting Consumers: Financial Data Security in the Age of Computer Hackers.” Moy’s written testimony is available here.

    (Laura Moy testifying before the House Financial Services Committee)
  • Congratluations to OTI! Combined with Kevin Bankston’s April 29 testimony on encryption technology and possible U.S. policy responses, delivered before a subcommittee of the House Oversight and Government Reform, and Moy’s previous testimony on data security and breach notification, last week’s hearings will bring the total number of Congressional hearings at which OTI has testified in the space of two months time to four.
  • On May 12, Peter W. Singer gave the keynote speech  at the Kingston Conference on National Security, on the topic of robots and war.
  • On Thursday May 14, Rebecca MacKinnon spoke at the Conference on Internet Governance and Cyber-Security, presented by Columbia University School of International and Public Affairs(SIPA) and the Global Commission on Internet Governance (GCIG). Hollie Russon-Gilman also served as a rapporteur.
  • Tim Maurer spoke about Computer Security Incident Response Teams at the annual Freedom Online Coalition conference in Mongolia and gave a presentation on cybersecurity at the National Assembly in Seoul, Korea.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Chris Leonard was featured on the May 17 episode of Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, talking about contract farming and the chicken industry.

    (Host John Oliver, referencing and featuring Chris Leonard’s research on chicken farmers)
  • ISP Senior Fellow Nadia Oweidat's work on social media and extremism was featured in an Washington Post op-ed by David Ignatius.
  • Peter W. Singer wrote a piece in Popular Science about a Chinese companying betting on an Ukranian cargo plane.
  • ISP research fellow Tara Maller wrote a post in Blogs of War about mobilizing women for cybersecurity.
  • Levi Tilleman placed a piece on Toyota's Mirai fuel cell vehicle in Fortune, spoke on a panel on autonomous vehicles organized by the State Dept at Brookings which was covered by Cspan.
  • Hollie Russon-Gillman was quoted in Fast Company article about urban innovation.
  • Leah Douglas had an article published in Slate about a proposed checkoff program for organic foods. The checkoff program would institute a mandatory tax for organic producers to fund a national marketing campaign for organic products. The article discusses how checkoff programs have historically favored the interests of large, corporate producers and how many small organic farmers are angry about the checkoff proposal.
  • Tyler Bugg’s write-up of Profits & Purpose's event on urban green innovation was picked up by TIME.

title: Bergen Publishes Three Stories for CNN, Fishman Discusses bin Laden on PBS NewsHour, and More
html:
POLICY

  • On May 21, Tomicah Tillemann delivered the keynote address at the World Bank's Global Development Finance Forum in Rotterdam.
  • Sharon Burke traveled to Taiwan with a delegation led by John Huntsman, former Governor of Utah and Ambassador to China.
  • Onalytica, a marketing business that uses analytics to measure the influence of various brands on topics that range from consumer electronics to health care, just did one on cybersecurity. New America had 3 of the top 30 most influential individual voices on cybersecurity influencers - Kevin Bankston, Shane Harris, & Peter W. Singer. New America itself was 18th overall in brand, and the only think tank on the list.
  • On May 8, Sarah Morris participated on the opening panel for the Federal Communications Bar Association's Annual Seminar last Friday, May 8th. She discussed the short- and long-term impacts of the FCC's Net Neutrality rules for consumers and innovators.
  • OTI officially moved to intervene in the litigation challenging the FCC's Net Neutrality rules, which the Court granted this week (thanks to some nice work by Sarah Morris!). Intervention means that OTI will be an official party to the litigation, participating in defense of the FCC. OTI joins many other public interest and industry representatives who have moved to intervene in recent weeks.
  • Congratulations to Rebecca MacKinnon, on being awarded a Shuttleworth Foundation Flash Grant in support of her work! The Foundation asked their Fellows “to seek out and nominate an impressive change agent, who may not be able to concentrate on their brilliant idea yet” to help them bring the idea forward.

EVENTS

  • Sharon Burke spoke at the UC Davis NextSTEPS conference on sustainable transportation.
  • The Museum of the City of New York, which recently co-hosted a event with Georgia Levenson Keohane called The New New York Activists: Urban Green Innovators, included a mention of the April 27th event, a link to the event video, a link to Tyler Bugg’s take-away in TIME, in their latest newsletter to 35,000 people.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Peter Bergen had the three lead stories on CNN.com.

    Peter broke the story of the unprecedented number of bin Laden documents released this week. That piece was read by 2 million readers.
  • Finally, Peter’s rebuttal to Sy Hersh's story that the bin Laden raid was faked and Obama lied about all aspects of the raid was also read by 2 million readers, and was cited by media outlets around the world. Peter’s story on newly revealed bin Laden photos received more than 30 million page views.
  • Brian Fishman appeared on the PBS Newshour on May 21, to discuss what the recently released Bin Laden documents reveal.

    (Brian Fishman speaks with The News Hour’s Gwen Ifill about the Bin Laden documents)
  • Sharon Burke published piece on China's Energy Security in the Weekly Wonk, which Slate also ran.
  • Hollie Russon Gilman published pieces in Civic Hall and also Brookings’ TechTank on Bloomberg's new Work Whats Cities initiative.
  • Steve Burd’s new policy paper, Out-of-State Student Arms Race: How Public Universities Use Merit Aid to Recruit Nonresident Students, was widely covered. Steve wrote a column about it in The Hechinger Report, and the paper also received mentions in Buzzfeed, The Washington Post, Bloomberg Business, The Chronicle of Higher Education, US News and World Report, Inside Higher Ed, CBS News, and TIME.
  • Kevin Carey published an article in the New York Times’ The Upshot, about how in-state tuition is slowly disappearing, and also referenced Steve Burd’s work.
  • In a recent Washington Post column, Britain resigns as a world power, New America Board Member, Fareed Zakaria references the work of fellow New America Board Member, Walter Russell Mead.

title: Congress Passes OTI-Supported USA FREEDOM Act, Four New Americans Contribute to Washington Monthly, and More
html:
POLICY

  • Last week, Congress passed the USA FREEDOM Act, which OTI strongly supported. The USA FREEDOM Act is Congress' first major surveillance reform bill to pass since the Snowden disclosures began two years ago. OTI has been a leader in the reform effort, and helped to draft the bill, which will ban NSA bulk collection under several domestic surveillance authorities and will significantly increase transparency and government accountability. OTI Director Kevin Bankston and Policy Counsel Robyn Greene worked to build support for the USA FREEDOM Act in Congress and with Administration officials, and led OTI's Stronger Internet Coalition in bringing together and amplifying the reform efforts of the advocacy community and the private sector.
  • Herb Lin at Stanford has accepted the invitation to join the Academic Advisory Network for the Global Cybersecurity Norms and Resilience Project, a great win for the Initiative and our efforts to connect with other grantees!
  • On June 3, Chris Leonard participated in a Congressional staff briefing on the poultry industry (Contract Retaliation Protection for Farmers), hosted by Rep. Marcy Kaptur and attended by about 60 Democratic and Republican staffers.

PUBLICATIONS

  • Peter W. Singer’s cybersecurity book was added to the 2015 US Air Force professional reading list.
  • Sharon Burke and Emily Schneider published an article, Enemy Number One for the Electric Grid: Mother Nature, examining the risks, vulnerabilities and threats facing the grid in The SAIS Review of International Affairs’ new volume.
  • ISP Senior fellow Chris Fussell co-wrote a new book with General Stanley McChrystal, Team of Teams: New Rules of Engagement for a Complex World. Deirdre Latour, chief communications officer for GE tweeted "This book is one of the most shared at GE right now..

EVENTS

  • On June 4, Opportunity@Work hosted a great event on connecting talent with opportunity in the digital age, featuring Byron Auguste, NYT Columnist Tom Friedman, Senator Mark Warner, Senator Mark Warner, LinkedIn Co-Founder Allen Blue, and former US CTO Aneesh Chopra.
  • On May 29, Sharon Burke participated in a national Webinar hosted by ASU on the Future of Sustainable Transportation Fuels.
  • On June 4, Rebecca MacKinnon spoke at a Council on Foreign Relations roundtable, discussing where Snowden’s debate now stands and where it might be heading in the future.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Monica Potts, Phil Longman, Lee Drutman, and Konstantain Kakaes all contributed pieces to the June/July/August 2015 issue of The Washington Monthly! Monica had the cover story, which looks at the downside of the sharing economy. Many of the youngest Gen-Xer's and oldest Millennials are working in freelance careers, supplementing their incomes or saving money by using the sharing economy, but at the same time they're not buying homes, building wealth, or saving for retirement.
  • Anne-Marie Slaughter published her latest article in Project Syndicate on “New-Model Development Finance”.
  • Peter W. Singer broke news on a massive new Chinese drone, that may be the largest in the world, and is designed to hunt stealth planes and ships.
  • Chris Leonard has an excellent article (A Murder Most Fowl! Who’s Murdering Thousands of Chickens in South Carolina?) in Bloomberg Businessweek (online and in print).
  • Liza Mundy has an excellent piece in this month's Atlantic about women and political leadership, called “Playing the Granny Card.”
  • Bretton Woods II’s progress pledge was profiled in a Nationswell article last week (also quoting Tomicah Tillemann) and was their top story of the day.
  • Virginia Eubanks published an article in The Nation, “System Failure: The High-Tech Way to Slash Public Benefits.”It appears in the June 15 special issue on the politics of technology, guest edited by Leah Hunt-Hendrix and Astra Taylor.
  • Michael Lind’s article on The Case for Ecomodernsim received a lot of attention on Reddit and on Twitter.
  • ISP Senior Fellow Nadia Oweidat was on TV in Cairo, on the popular TV channel Cairo and People.
  • Mondoweiss covered two recent New America NYC events with feature-length articles -- the 5/28 event on the impacts of last summer's war in Gaza and the 6/4 debate between Peter Beinart and Yousef Munayyer, calling it a "historic encounter."

title: ISP Trio Joins CNN's The Situation Room, Circuit Court Sides with OTI to Delay Net Neutrality Rules, and More
html:
A New America Hat Trick!

On June 9, three members of New America’s International Security Program (L-R: Phil Mudd, Peter Bergen, and Doug Ollivant) appeared on CNN’s The Situation Room.

POLICY

  • On June 11, the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals sided with OTI, the FCC, and dozens of advocacy groups and companies when it rejected a request to delay the FCC's net neutrality rules. By rejecting the stay, the court cleared the path for the net neutrality rules to go into effect Friday as scheduled. This is the first time since January 2014 that net neutrality laws are in effect, restoring online freedom and keeping the Internet a level playing field for us all. (Read Sarah Morris’ statement here).
  • The White House announced on Tuesday June 9, that it will adopt an HTTPS-only standard for all federal websites, which is an important step toward better Internet security. OTI Technologists Jordan McCarthy and Nat Meysenburg wrote comments in support of the proposal last month.
  • OTI filed comments with the Broadband Opportunity Council, a group consisting of representatives from 25 federal agencies whose goal is to increase broadband access and adoption, outlining a series of short term and long term steps that the federal government can take to bridge the digital divide. Those comments were written by Sarah Morris and Danielle Kehl.
  • On June 9, Tim Maurer and Robert Morgus briefed a high level delegation from Portugal on cybersecurity policy including two officials from the President's office"

EVENTS

  • On June 10, Sharon Burke served as the moderator for a National Academies of Science panel on "Novel Power Sources," which was co-hosted by the Office of the Director for National Intelligence.
  • Levi Tillemann keynoted the Nomura Investment Forum Asia in Singapore.
  • Last week, Liza Mundy gave the keynote address at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, on the topic of women in science. Coincidentally, the speech occurred just a few days after Sir Tim Hunt made his now-infamous comments about the "trouble with girls" in science labs.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Lee Drutman was mentioned in Thomas Edsall’s June 10 New York Times column, The Lobbying Bonanza. Lee’s book, The Business of America is Lobbying, is mentioned in The Economist, and he was also interviewed on Marketplace.
  • Josh Stager was quoted in the Washington Post over FCC markup in House Appropriations bill.
  • Kevin Carey was quoted in Marketwatch and Inside Higher Ed. Kevin’s book, “The End of College,” was also one of the recommended readings on a Washington Post summer reading list from college admissions counselors and deans.
  • Jason DeLisle and Kevin Carey are both quoted in a Forbes article, about loan forgiveness and reacting to Lee Siegel’s article urging students to default on their student loans.
  • Lindsey Tepe was quoted in an Education Week article about states’ college-readiness policies.
  • Shane Harris was on the BBC World Service, and on the Diane Rehm Show's International News Roundup on June 12.

title: Slaughter and Garcia Host California Showcase, Opportunity@Work Featured in New York Times Column, and More
html:
Congratulations to everyone who helped make the California event a success! On June 17th, Anne-Marie Slaughter and Megan Garcia hosted a California Showcase that brought together high level policy thinkers, tech leaders, social sector innovators, and journalists to tell stories about disrupting government in San Francisco. The event featured New America’ own Shane Harris along with former USCTO Todd Park, Jen Pahlka, Founder of Code for America, and Carmen Rojas of the Workers Lab, and was met with rave reviews.

(Megan Garcia speaking at the California Showcase)

POLICY

  • Suzanne DiMaggio convened the latest round of the U.S.-Iran Track II Dialogue she directs. The discussions, which were held in Copenhagen on 17-19 June, focused on the nuclear negotiations, post-deal scenarios, and a range of regional issues including Iraq, Syria, ISIS, Iran-Saudi relations, and Afghanistan.

PUBLICATIONS/RESEARCH

  • Rebecca MacKinnon and Priya Kumar share that research is now in full swing for RDR’s 2015 Corporate Accountability Index. The Index, to be unveiled in early November, will evaluate 16 telecommunication and Internet companies on 31 indicators examining policies and disclosures affecting users’ freedom of expression and privacy.
  • OTI just published an original case study -- looking at how technology was used on the Seth Moulton campaign as part of a broader initiative they are doing on addressing tech/policy divide

EVENTS

  • Tim Maurer and Robert Morgus’ policy paper, CSIRT Basics for Policy-makers, was the topic of a roundtable discussion led by Co-authors Isabel Skierka and Mirko Hohmann at the Forum of Incident Response and Security Teams annual conference in Berlin (FIRST is the global organization of CSIRTs). Tim also presented the paper to policy-makers and CSIRT operators at the National CSIRT meeting this past weekend in Berlin.
  • Ian Wallace and Trey Herr spoke to a group of Indian and Pakistani students about cyber conflict at GWU's Sandia National Labs and Cyber Security Policy and Research Institute workshop.
  • The Cybersecurity Initiative publicly launched their National Cybersecurity Fellows network which generated buzz on Twitter and made it into Politico's Morning Cyber.
  • Sharon Burke spoke at the Atlantic Council, about "Climate Security: The Next 'Battle Ground'?"
  • The keynote speaker for the June 16, 2015 U.S. Federal Courts Judicial Prayer Breakfast was New America Senior Fellow David Gray, talking about work family issues.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Anne-Marie Slaughter published a great opinion piece in The Washington Post over Father’s Day weekend, Don’t worry, working moms: Just leave Dad in charge at home, which gave a nice shout-out to Conor Williams of New America’s Early Education Initiative. Anne-Marie was also referenced in a separate Washington Post piece, a book review on “leaning in” for dads.
  • Thomas Friedman of The New York Times recently wrote a column about Opportunity@Work and the great event the Opportunity@Work team hosted at New America on Connecting Talent with Opportunity in the Digital Age. With leadership from Byron Auguste and the McKinsey Global Institute, the event also featured Senator Mark Warner, Allen Blue (Co-Founder of LinkedIn), Aneesh Chopra (Former US Chief Technology Officer), Susan Lund of McKinsey Global Institute and Friedman.
  • Michael Lind wrote an article for POLITICO Magazine, Jeb and Hillary Have No New Ideas. Neither Does Anyone Else.
  • David Sterman had his debut solo article on CNN.com, A death trap for al Qaeda leaders?
  • Peter Bergen published an article on CNN.com, Will whack-a-mole strategy succeed vs. terrorists?
  • Peter Bergen and David Sterman co-authored an article about the attack in Charleston, Call it terrorism in Charleston.
  • Data from the International Security Program’s homegrown extremism database was cited in a June 16 New York Times’ opinion column.
  • On June 21,  the leading independent Jordanian newspaper, Al-Ghad, published a page long interview with ISP fellow Nadia Oweidat on the U.S. strategy on terrorism and other foreign policy issues.
  • Shane Harris published a Daily Beast article, Drones Turn al Qaeda Killers on Each Other.
  • Julian Zelizer published an opinion piece on CNN.com, asking, “Why are so many running for President?”
  • Jane Carr published a scholarly article about activism through storytelling, early 20th century car culture, and how a little-known travelling bookseller used both to change her world this month in American Quarterly, the journal of the American Studies Association.
  • Amy Laitinen was quoted in an Inside Higher Ed article about competency-based education.
  • Abbie Lieberman was quoted in a Minnesota Public Radio piece about the benefits of pre-K and Head Start.
  • Jason Delisle was quoted in a National Journal article about Elizabeth Warren’s proposal for debt-free college.
  • Stephen Burd wrote an article for The Hechinger Report’s Higher Ed Watch, on The perils of enrolling in for-profit colleges.
  • Susan Blumenthal, M.D., Senior Fellow in Health Policy, published an op-ed on Ending HIV in American Women in Everyday Health.

title: Bergen and Sterman Publish Lead Story in New York Times, New America Trends Nationwide on Facebook, and More
html:
THE NEW YORK TIMES LEAD AND TRENDING ON FACEBOOK!

  • Peter Bergen and David Sterman are the force behind the lead of the June 24 print edition of the New York Times, Homegrown Extremists Tied to Deadlier Toll Than Jihadists in U.S. Since 9/11. The piece features the International Security Program’s work on homegrown extremism. It was the lead story on the NYT’s website that day, and generated a significant amount of media and public interest in the ISP’s work on homegrown extremists. By the end of the day, New America’s work on homegrown extremists was trending on Facebook (see below).
  • Peter Bergen was subsequently interviewed on NPR’s All Things Considered about right-wing extremists. Peter also wrote two articles for CNN.com: one on U.S. hostage policy, and one about the three terror attacks that took place on Friday.
  • David Sterman was interviewed on KNPR radio about domestic terrorists, specifically in relation to last year’s shooting of two police officers in Las Vegas.

POLICY

  • Anne-Marie Slaughter received a letter from Senator Patrick Leahy, one of the sponsors of the USA FREEDOM Act, who wrote to personally thank her for OTI's work on the bill, noting Kevin Bankston and Robyn Greene’s contributions specifically.
  • Peter W. Singer briefed the USAF strategy team on real world lessons from his new book, Ghost Fleet.

PUBLICATIONS

  • Peter W. Singer’s new book, Ghost Fleet, comes on June 30th. Check out a related piece on VICE about artwork related to the book, The Art of World War III. Peter and his book are also profiled in a June 28 Wall Street Journal article.

EVENTS

  • Suzanne DiMaggio participated in a two-day conference convened by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund on "U.S.-Iran Relations after a Nuclear Agreement" at the RBF Pocantico Conference Center on June 22-23.
  • New Models of Policy Change partnered with the Brennan Center to host a standing-room only launch event. Heather Hurlburt moderated a panel that included Texas conservative lawyer and founder of Right on Crime Marc Levin, Brennan's Inimai Chettiar and Slate's Jamelle Bouie, with a surprise appearance by Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts. Showcasing the trans-partisan and diverse nature of the criminal justice reform coalition, the panel looked at the state of cross-partisan cooperation for reform at the state and national levels, and how partisan pressures around the 2016 presidential election will affect those partnerships.
  • Robyn Greene spoke on two panels on cybersecurity and national security last week. on Thursday, she spoke at "Cybersecurity: Managing the Risks of the Digital Frontier,” where the keynote speaker was House Homeland Security Committee Chairman, Representative McCaul and she was on a panel with Robert Knake, Director of Cybersecurity Policy for the White House National Security and other experts. On Friday, she spoke on panel on cybersecurity information sharing at the SINET Innovation Summit, moderated by Daniel W. Sutherland, Associate General Counsel, National Protection and Programs Directorate, Office of the General Counsel, US Department of Homeland Security.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Anne-Marie Slaughter wrote a new column for Project Syndicate, “Securing the Internet Commons.”
  • Conor Williams will be writing for the Seventy Four, a new education news outlet. This was mentioned in several articles: Wall Street Journal, Education Week, Education World, and Washington Free Beacon.
  • Steve Burd's paper Out-of-State Student Arms Race was featured in the College Solution.
  • Ben Miller received coverage twice this week in the Politico Morning Education newsletter (and here) for his paper released Tuesday.

title: New America wins US Social Policy award from Prospect Magazine, Chaudry Profiled by Carnegie, and More
html:
New America won an award in US Social Policy from Prospect Magazine! (Categories for US think tanks included: Economic and Financial, Social Policy, Energy and the Environment, and International Affairs). For those who may not be familiar with Prospect, Peter Bergen describes it as "easily the best serious general interest magazine in the UK" - a mix between The Atlantic and Democracy. In their words, we won because, we are "a think tank whose work was called [by the judges] “ambitious,” and “wide-reaching,” ranging from analysis of American families to higher education reform. It is “not afraid to challenge cherished American notions of class mobility,” a judge commented, “and has been becoming more and more visible on the international stage.” Congrats to all of you!

Congratulations to ISP Fellow Rabia Chaudry, on being named a “Great Immigrant” by Carnegie Corporation of New York as part of their July 4th tribute. Rabia is one of 39 naturalized citizens to be honored for 2015. Every July 4 since 2006, Carnegie Corporation has recognized the contributions of immigrants through its “Great Immigrants: The Pride of America” initiative.

Informing young minds!

  • Getting beyond the beltway, New America's work on surveillance policy including the report on the cost of surveillance by Danielle Kehl, Kevin Bankston, Robyn Greene and Rob Morgus as well as the report on whether NSA bulk surveillance prevents terrorism by Peter Bergen, David Sterman, Emily Schneider, and Bailey Cahall form the foundation of evidence produced by Dartmouth's Debate Institute and will thus likely be used by hundreds of high school students throughout the next year as they debate US surveillance policy.
  • ISP’s report “Do NSA’s Bulk Surveillance Programs Stop Terrorists?” (by Peter Bergen, Emily Schneider, David Sterman, and Bailey Cahall) will also be adapted and featured in an upcoming textbook, Current Controversies: Domestic Surveillance, by Cengage Learning.

Policy

  • Tomicah Tillemann and the Bretton Woods II initiative co-hosted a major event at the UN Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa with the heads of OPIC, the EBRD, Save the Children, and the Center for Global Development.

Publications

  • Publishers Weekly included Katherine Zoepf’s forthcoming book, Excellent Daughters: The Secret Lives of the Young Women Who are Transforming the Arab World, in its Fall Highlights issue last week: “Young journalist Zoepf tells the never-before-reported story of a new generation of Arab women who are questioning authority, changing societies, and leading revolutions, and bringing a new understanding of the changing Arab societies.” Katherine’s book will be published in January 2016.

Events

  • Tomicah Tillemann is speaking at the ONE Campaign's Data Revolution event together with Treasury Secretary Jack Lew and Liberian President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf.
  • New America NYC hosted the launch event for Strategist and Senior Fellow Peter W. Singer's new book, Ghost Fleet: A Novel of the Next World War.

Major Media

  • Suzanne DiMaggio discussed the Iran nuclear negotiations with members of The New York Times' Editorial Board on July 13. And she was interviewed by The Wall Street Journal on July 12 for an upcoming profile on Iran's Foreign Minister Javad Zarif.
  • Sharon Burke and Emily Schneider published an article in Slate, looking at the threat of the electromagnetic pulse.
  • Michael Lind wrote an article for POLITICO Magazine, “How the South Skews America,” and was quoted in a CNN article about “Southernomics.”
  • Reid Cramer’s article on how the sharing economy hurts Millennials ran on Time.com.
  • Heather Hurlburt published an article in Defense One, “How to Win a National Security Election Without Really Trying.”
  • Conor Williams wrote an opinion piece in The Seventy Four about education reform. He was mentioned in a Fortune interview by Campbell Brown, The Seventy Four's co-founder, and his opinion piece was mentioned in Washington Monthly.
  • Stephen Burd wrote a blog post in Washington Monthly about Newark's efforts to increase its number of college graduates. Additionally, his blog post on gainful employment was mentioned as part of the lead story in Politico's Morning Education.
  • Peter W. Singer’s new book continues to receive mentions in the press, including in The Wall Street Journal, The Intercept, The Diplomat, US News and World Report, VICE, Defense One, and Christian Science Monitor. Peter also wrote an article relating to the book for CNN.com and did an interview with C-SPAN’s Washington Journal.
  • ISP intern Haley Peters made her CNN.com debut, in an article co-authored with Peter Bergen, “The sky didn’t fall after July fourth.”
  • Barak Barfi and New America Board Member David Bradley are mentioned in a New Yorker article about the families of U.S. hostages held in Syria.

title: Breadwinning and Caregiving receives three-year $900,000 gift, Kakaes and Greenwood host a half-day conference on humanitarian drones, and More
html:
Congratulations to the Breadwinning and Caregiving Program! Irene Pollin, long-time therapist, writer, mother, and wife of the late Abe Pollin, has made a 3 year $900,000 gift!

Events

  • Konstantin Kakaes and Faine Greenwood hosted a half-day long conference on humanitarian drones on July 22nd, coinciding with the release of their "Drones and Aerial Observation : New Technologies for Property Rights, Human Rights, and Global Development," a primer to the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles for civilian purposes. Panel topics included the United Nations usage of drones for peacekeeping in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, drones uses in conservation, the practicalities of UAV mapping, how drone imagery can used to secure property rights, and other topics.
  • Suzanne DiMaggio participated in a panel discussion on Negotiating the Gulf: How a Nuclear Agreement Would Redefine GCC-Iran Relations convened by the Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington on 21 July 2015. Watch the video here.
  • Levi Tillemann led a half-day seminar on markets, regulation and technology forcing policies for the consortium of Pacific Northwest EPA Directors, which includes the EPA heads for Washington State, Oregon, Idaho, British Columbia, Alberta and Alaska.
  • Last week, Tim Maurer presented New America's Global Cyber Definitions Database at the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe based in Vienna.

Policy

  • Anne-Marie Slaughter and Suzanne DiMaggio joined a bipartisan group of 60 U.S. national security leaders who co-signed a statement supporting the comprehensive nuclear deal with Iran. Read the statement here.
  • Yascha Mounk published an open letter to Germany's Social Democratic Party (SPD) in The Nation, Die Zeit as well as the Greek paper Kathimerini. He had been a member of the SPD since he was 13, but in this letter resigned in protest over its treatment of Greece. Yascha appeared on The Debate at France 24 and German public radio in appearances related to the public resignation.
  • In a win for OTI, the FCC last week attached conditions to AT&T's merger with DirecTV — including the first-ever conditions concerning "interconnection," the process by which AT&T exchanges traffic from its customers to the rest of the Internet. For the past two months, Josh Stager and Measurement Lab lobbied the FCC for an interconnection condition in response to data revealing that AT&T customers are not getting the broadband speeds they paid for due to interconnection-related congestion.
  • The FCC released the merger order Only July 27, which cites OTI's research.
  • On July 21, the Rochester New York Public Defender's Office reached out to New America's International Security Program regarding its database of homegrown extremism cases. Though ISP was unable to help with the specific questions, the office commented that they found the database very useful in their work.

Publications

  • A book Julian Zelizer co-edited and wrote a chapter for, Medicare and Medicaid at 50: America’s Entitlement Programs in the Age of Affordable Care, was published by Oxford University Press this month. The collection has been written about inThe Washington Post,TIME, and in a piece Julian wrote for CNN.
  • David Gray had a chapter published in the Lewis Center's book "Leading Ideas to Reach Young Adults
  • Hollie Russon-Gilman contributed to a book on data and development for the World Bank, “Deliberation and Development.”

Major Media

  • Suzanne DiMaggio was interviewed on the Iranian nuclear deal and its impacts on relations with the U.S. and the region by a range of publications/media outlets, including MSNBC’s Weekend with Alex Witt (19 July 2015), HuffPost Live, Bloomberg, The Los Angeles Times, Middle East Eye, USA Today,International Business Times (also here, here and here), Voice of America, Rudaw, and The Wall Street Journal.
  • Peter Bergen and David Sterman published an article on CNN.com about the shootings in Chattanooga,A history of attacks against U.S. military installations. David was also interviewed on MSNBC on July 16, discussing the shooting. Peter Bergen and Courtney Schuster contributed another article to CNN.com,The golden age of terrorism.
  • Anne-Marie Slaughter’s most recent column for Project Syndicate,Europe’s Civil War, addresses the recent negotiations over Greek’s debt.
  • Lee Drutman wrote an article for the National Review, Corporate Lobbying is the Ultimate Tragedy of the Commons.
  • Hua Hsu published a piece inThe New Yorker about how loudness became the signature of the last decade of pop music--how noise became music, and how it has shaped the techniques, textures, and tastes of its producers and consumers.
  • TNR headlined its website with an article by Heather Hurlburt on the future of humanitarian intervention.
  • Sharon Burke’s piece No Such Thing as a Green War or a Bad Peace just came out in the August 2015 Environmental Law and Policy Annual Review.
  • Yascha Mounk published a piece in CNN Opinion about how to get the public on board with action against climate change (hint: it's not telling them that they shouldn't eat beef because of global warming.) Yascha also also appeared on The Debate at France 24 and was interviewed on German public radio to discuss the situation in Greece.
  • Peter W. Singer published an article on Reuters,The weapons the U.S. needs for a war it doesn’t want, and was quoted in POLITICO Pro about how the Chrysler recall could shift relations between automakers and hackers. Peter was also interviewed on NPR’s All Things Considered, in a story about attempts to operate drones in swarms.
  • Liza Mundy was recently interviewed on on Australian radio and Radio New Zealand about her Atlantic piece onPlaying the Granny Card.
  • Kevin Carey wrote an article in The New York Times about the way that universities are an illusion.

title: New Class of Fellows is Chosen for 2016, Political Reform Launches its New Blog on Vox, and More
html:
Congrats to the new class of Fellows! We are still keeping this private for now (so no link to a press release yet), but you should have received an email last week with the news. And if it’s a link you want, then use this one to RSVP to the party!

Policy

  • OTI’s Wireless Future Project racked up two significant wins at the FCC’s August meeting. The Commission adopted two Orders related to next year’s big auction of TV band spectrum. In one, they agreed to WiFu’s proposal that a sufficient amount of unlicensed spectrum to support “Super Wi-Fi” will be available in every market after the auction. In the other, they adopted many of WiFu’s proposals to make unlicensed use of the so-called “TV White Space” channels far more useful, particularly for rural and community broadband efforts.
  • Peter W. Singer briefed lessons from his new book to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs and his leadership team, gave speeches to the US Army, US Navy (2x), US Air Force, and Cyber Command.

Publications

  • Drone Wars, a book edited by Peter Bergen and Daniel Rothenberg, was reviewed by H-Diplo and Military Review [link to abstract]

Major Media

  • Political Reform launched its new blog on Vox, with Lee Drutman’s piece on the power of the gun lobby in the U.S. Lee was also published in CNN, talking about a potential Lawrence Lessig Presidential run, and in the Washington Post, with a proposal for a better way to test if someone is ready to be President.
  • Faine Greenwood published an article in Make about “drone jerks,” and a piece in Slate about Peru’s drone archaeology program
  • Lee Drutman appeared on WJLA’s Newstalk with Bruce DePuyt, talking about the value of debates.
  • Mark Schmitt's book review of "The Speechwriter" on the Polyarchy Blog at Vox.
  • Peter W. Singer was published in Wired + Popular Science and appeared on both NPR and Fox.
  • Susan Blumenthal, M.D., published an article, Advancing Health with Information Technology in the 21st Century, on The Huffington Post.
  • Rebecca Mackinnon was quoted in the Wall Street Journal about China’s attempt to rewrite the rules of the Internet.
  • Joshua Stager explained Verizon’s role in Net Neutrality regulation in Morning Consult’s FCC Will Head to Court To Defend Net Neutrality … Again
  • OTI’s Cost of Connectivity Report was referenced in CNET’s In New York, Starbucks and Now Internet on Almost Every Corner
  • Emily Hong, OTI’s newest tour-de-force, wrote a widely shared piece on Lessons From Seoul’s Two Sharing Economies for Tech Crunch
  • Emily Hong’s piece Who Is David and Who Is Goliath? on Google v. Hood, originally featured in the Weekly Wonk, was picked up by Slate.
  • Kevin Bankston demonstrated the need for cellphone encryption in his Future Tense article The Numbers Don’t Lie: Smartphone Encryption Will Help More Than It Hurts Them
  • Michael Calabrese explains how changing retransmission rules would level the playing field in Morning Consult’s article, FCC Looking to Review Retransmission Fees for Broadcasters

title: Sen. Lisa Murkowski Credits Political Reform Event in her Support of Voting Rights Act Reauthorization, Carey Writes New York Times Article on College Scorecard, and More
html:
Thanks again to Peter Bergen, Kirsten Berg and all who made the Fellows Welcome party such a great success!

Policy

  • Sen. Lisa Murkowski’s credited ourPolitical Reform event with Ari Berman as the prompt for her to announce her support for the reauthorization of the Voting Rights Act.

Speaking Engagements

  • On 9/2, Lee Drutman provided closing remarks on the Corporate Reform Coalition's Big Tent Meeting at the AFL-CIO headquarters. Lee's commentary took after his book title: “The Business of America Is Lobbying: How Corporations Became More Political and Politics Became More Corporate.”
  • Suzanne DiMaggio was a guest speaker at a conference on "The Future of Iraq," which was held in Baghdad on September 2-3. Her remarks focused on governance and reconciliation, U.S. policy, and potential consequences/opportunities associated with the Iran nuclear deal.

Cool Stuff That’s Hard to Categorize

  • Just the announcement of the Fellows class scored one of them an agent. From Scott Silverstone - “There's been an interesting development in my book project that I wanted to let you know about, and I'd like to solicit any advice you might have on moving forward. Less than 24 hours after New America published the press release about the new fellows, I received an email from Andrew Wylie asking if I have representation for my current book (I do not).

Major Media

  • Kevin Carey wrote an article in The New York Times about the Department of Education's new College Scorecard. His piece was referenced in Politico's Morning Education. He also wrote an opinion piece in the Washington Post about how the reauthorization of No Child Left behind could strip certain powers away from future secretaries of education.
  • Emily Hong wrote Bridging the Digital Divide: A Critical Moment to Modernize the Lifeline Program, a piece that examines how the FCC must reform Lifeline in order to reduce barriers of access and strengthen minimum standards for Internet service for low-income households.
  • Lee Drutman was on the Matt Townsend radio show to talk about his book, "The Business of America is Lobbying".
  • Susan Blumenthal M.D. will be awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Roma in Italy for her leadership in health.
  • OTI Program Fellow, Jake Lapperuque was quoted in NextGov’s article Three Cybersecurity Alternatives if CISA Fails, commenting on less controversial actions the Senate could take rather than pass the 22 controversial CISA amendments. NextGov also highlighted National Journal’s coverage of all 22 CISA amendments from August 26 which featured Robyn Greene’s analysis of Senator Tom Cotton’s amendment.
  • Remember to check out the new Polyarchy Blog. Some recent highlights:
    • On Larry Lessig's Presidential Campaign by Mark Schmitt
    • On AIPAC and the Iran Deal by Heather Hurlburt and Lee Drutman
    • Will “decoherence” be the doom of American democracy? by Lee Drutman
  • On 9/9 Heather Hurlburt was on HuffPost Live to talk about the Israel lobby's influence (or lack of it) in DC.
  • Mei Fong was on the radio show Warren Olney's "To the Point" talking about the slump in China stocks and the Tianjin explosion, and how this relates to its political landscape. Other guests were Clay Shirkey, Jacob Soll and Damien Ma.
  • Suzanne DiMaggio authored a piece on "Rebuilding Relations with Iran," which was included in a collection of essays entitled Confrontation of Conciliation: How the Nuclear Agreement is Reshaping GCC-Iran Relations published by the Arab Gulf States Institute in Washington. Read it here.
  • DiMaggio was also interviewed by the Tehran-based website Iran Review about the nuclear deal and the future of U.S.-Iran relations. Read the interview here.
  • Stephen Burd was featured on NPR's Morning Edition on September 3, speaking about George Washington University's decision to go test-optional.
  • Laura Bornfreund and Lisa Guernsey wrote an article for CNN on the transition between early childhood education and kindergarten.
  • Rachel Fishman was on NPR's All Things Considered on September 14, about the Obama administration's recent changes to the FAFSA.
  • Amy Laitinen was quoted in the Wall Street Journal on the Department of Education's new College Scorecard.
